Charles Hardin Holley (September 7, 1936 ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬Å“ February 3, 1959) known professionally as Buddy Holly, was an American singer-songwriter and a pioneer of rock and roll. Although his success lasted only a year and a half before his death in an airplane crash, Holly is described by critic Bruce Eder as "the single most influential creative force in early rock and roll." His works and innovations inspired and influenced contemporary and later musicians, notably The Beatles, The Rolling Stones, Bob Dylan, and Eric Clapton, and exerted a profound influence on popular music. Holly was among the first group of inductees to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1986. In 2004, Rolling Stone ranked Holly #13 among "The Fifty Greatest Artists of All Time".

Listen to Me: Buddy Holly is a tribute album to rock ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‹Å“n roll pioneer Buddy Holly, in celebration of what would have been his 75th birthday in 2011. The album was released by Verve Forecast in the United States on 6 September 2011 (Holly's birthday was 7 September 1936). Contributing artists include Patrick Stump and Stevie Nicks. A tribute event was held at the Music Box Theater in Hollywood. The album debuted on the US Billboard 200 at number 135.


Released: September 6, 2011

Genre: Pop, contemporary, alternative rock

Length: 43:53
